div1.p: Hurd shares his recollections of Walter Reed at Johns Hopkins and later.

div1.head: Letter from Henry M. Hurd to Caroline Latimer, February 11, 1905
div1.opener:
Form 1310,000-7-11-1904.
THE JOHNS HOPKINS HOSPITAL,
NORTH BROADWAY,
Baltimore, February 11th, 1905 190
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
HENRY W. HURD, M. D.
Superintendent.
Dear Dr. Latimer:--
div1.p:
In accordance with your request, I write to give
you some impressions of Dr. Walter Reed.

When the Hospital first opened, but before the establishment
of the Medical School, it was customary for us to receive physicians
who had graduated in medicine elsewhere for ward instruction and for
laboratory courses. One day, about 1890, Dr. Reed came to me and said
that he had been detailed by Surgeon General Baxter to come to Baltimore
partly to attend to certain duties at Fort McHenry, but mainly to prepare
himself for his examination and promotion by the opportunities afforded
here for study. He very modestly asked me what he had better do, and I
advised him as well as I could. I suggested that he take courses in
pathology and bacteriology, in addition to certain clinical courses in
general medicine and surgery. He seemed much interested, but said un-
fortunately the Surgeon General had forbidden him to give any attention
to laboratory work, and had informed him curtly and pointedly that his the
object in detailing him to come here was that he might better familiar-
ize himself with the care of sick soldiers. Under the circumstances he
felt that he could not in honor pursue any laboratory courses. He be-
gan to take clinical courses here and continued for some weeks, but
upon the sudden death of Surgeon General Baxter, after securing the
permission of the new Surgeon General, he devoted himself to laboratory
courses in pathology and bacteriology, and soon was known as one of our

best and most industrious workers. From this time on, as long as he
remained in Baltimore, I saw much of him and was always impressed
with his keenness of mind and his intense interest in the scientific
branches of medicine. Ever after, whenever he came to Baltimore, he
usually came to the Hospital.

The summer before his death, I met him on his way to Monterey,
where he had a summer cottage, and had a long conversation with him
about his work. He was especially interested in the typhoid fever in-
vestigation, carried on by a Committee of which he was a member and its connection with flies as carriers of contagion. He
also spoke at length of his work upon the causation of yellow fever,
especially the mosquito theory. I do not know how far this should be
published. He said to me, however, that before he went to Cuba he had
a long conference with Surgeon General Sternberg as to the lines of in-
vestigation of yellow fever. He suggested to General Sternberg that it
might be well to study the role of the mosquito in connection with the
development of yellow fever, and that General Sternberg said “No; that
has already been decided to be a useless investigation.” Subsequently,
however, when all other leads had failed, and the investigation seemed
destined to be fruitless, his thoughts recurred to the mosquito theory
and, in connection with Doctors Lazear and Carroll, he initiated the
experiments which resulted in the brilliant discovery.

I was much impressed, in this last conversation which I held
with him, with his enthusiasm and devotion to his scientific work. He
told me an incident which at that time made a strong impression upon

me: How that, when it was known in Cuba that volunteers were desired
who would submit to the inoculation by mosquitoes infected by yellow fever, two young men, pri-
vates in the Army, came to him and volunteered to submit to the experi-
ments. He talked with them rather fully and explained to them the
dangers and difficulties, and also added that a definite money compen-
sation would be paid to them. Both young men declined to receive the
money and said that their only object was to further scientific investi-
gation, whereupon Dr. Reed said, raising his hat respectfully, “I take
off my hat to you, gentlemen”.

It was evident to all who saw him during the last two years of
his life, that he was very much worn by his scientific labors, but it
was also evident that he felt most keenly the attempts which were made
by persons high in authority to rob him of his just fame for the work
which he had done. Personally, he was tall, somewhat slender, erect
in bearing and graceful in carriage. He was cordial and courteous in
manner, and instinctively made friends of all who came in contact with
him.

I think this is about what Dr. Kelly desired to know. If any
additions are needed, I will gladly make them.

closer.seg:
P. S. I am afraid you have not received the money for the last
book reviews. Miss Spicer will count them up, and the payment will be
made at once.
